title: Fixes #4393 - Fixed COPX Display for DW Inbnds (Lakes -> PC)
body:
Fixes #4393

# Summary of changes

Reordered agreement files in the compiler so that the 'catch-all' lines for BAGSO are underneath the ones for EIDW inbounds. This ensures that, when Lakes and PC West are split, the 290 descending via PENIL is the first line to be matched.

# Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/196298398-c98d069f-10aa-4fce-9887-255e40540120.png)

title: Fixes #4110 - Fixed Jersey Control COPX function
body:
Fixes #4110

# Summary of changes

- Updated sector names in agreements files
- Added guest ownership for West/South sectors to ensure COPX to London displays correctly (sector prediction)
- Expanded LFRR Low sector to ensure it surrounds the whole JJ CTR

# Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/196490429-808b79a7-e41a-400e-91c4-d35d1ac7c0e6.png)

title: Fixes #4438 - Fixed COPX display for LTMA deps via SITET/XAMAB
body:
Fixes #4438

# Summary of changes

- Removed 'catch-all' COPX for Paris, as this was always overriding the display for LTMA outbounds
- Moved S1 COPX via SITET/XAMAB to the end of the COPX section to ensure LTMA outbound lines are matched first
- Amended various lines to use SITET/XAMAB as FIXBEFORE

**Main change** - when EuroScope predicts traffic will not reach 290 by the boundary, it will display `COORD` 290 to indicate that the controller needs to coordinate the traffic with Paris (but only when Brest and Paris are split)

# Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/196235359-fed72240-e1ce-4b06-adbf-ed652ff20bc8.png)

title: won't fix: TC VATON -> TC LOREL - GW inbounds next sector prediction
body:
# What is the bug?
Online controllers:

- AC South
- AC Central
- TC Bandbox

EuroScope is predicting transfer from AC South to AC Central.

# What is the expected functionality?

Transfer from AC South to TC Bandbox (TC LOREL) descending FL160 via VATON.

# How can it be reproduced? 

Sweatbox

# Additional information

EuroScope isn't thinking the aircraft will descend into TC LOREL's airspace because of how long the EGGW STARs are now to ZAGZO. Might be able to make TC a guest in the applicable Central airspace for EGGW inbounds to fix this.

title: Fixes #4397 - Update Hawarden (EGNR) SMR
body:
Fixes #4397

# Summary of changes

Turns out the hold lines were there, but hidden by the regions which were in the wrong place. As there was no exising .kmz, I had to re-draw it all a bit, so new .kmz included (although it doesn't include the buildings). Some updates to the shape of the aprons etc have taken place since the last update too so they're included, and some superfluous GEO stuff is removed (mostly because it wasn't commented and I didn't know which bits were which).

But ultimately, holds should all be there and labelled now. I moved some of the existing hold labels to make them more legible as well :)

Added waypoints for 3 DME and 5 DME points on SANBA departures. MCT05 (normal FMC coding) is already taken so using alternative/non-conflicting format.

title: Duplicate fix definitions
body:
# What is in error?

Certain fixes have been duplicated in the sector file.

The task:
- Find where they're defined
- If it's a fix related to an IFP (Instrument Flight Procedure) at an airport, then it should be in Airports/EGxx/Fixes.txt - generally, fixes are defined on charts/in RNAV coding tables with greater precision than they are in ENR 4.4
- If a fix is defined at an airport level but also features in ENR 4.4, then add a commented line to Navaids/FIXES_UK.txt stating where it is defined
- If it's a fix on an FIR boundary that has duplicate definitions in UK and Non-UK, define in UK if it's featured in ENR 4.4, or Non-UK if not. Ideally, cross check the coordinates with the local AIP to ensure they're still correct.

Fixes are:

- [ ] NEVRI
- [ ] OSDEB
- [ ] TUFOZ
- [ ] ZOPHI

# Sources
Various

# File changes
TBC

title: Invalid/wrong ATIS frequencies

labels.name: ops-input-required
labels.description: Where other Ops staff input/work is required

body:
The current ES sector file edition (2021-13) does have some invalid/wrong ATIS frequencies:

- Kirkwall ATIS: 108.60 MHz (VOR frequency)
- Aberdeen ATIS: 114.30 MHz (VOR frequency) - there's another entry for Aberdeen ATIS which has the correct frequency
- Stornoway ATIS: 121.60 MHz - the eAIP says 115.10 MHz which is a VOR frequency, either, and 121.60 MHz is used for a non-ATS purpose ("Stornoway Fire Chief")

Source: eAIP https://nats-uk.ead-it.com/cms-nats/opencms/en/Publications/AIP/

Proposal: maybe simply remove all three frequencies stated above as they're either incorrect and/or unusable (VOR frequencies cannot be used for voice transmission in any FS)

Best regards,

Christoph Reule (1504233)

title: Inverness APP - N560 Southbound COPX Display
body:
# What is the bug?
On as EGPE_APP with SCO_CTR above. Traffic outbound via GUSSI N560. COPX not showing. Possibly not showing for other routes as well (no traffic on these routings to confirm this).

# What is the expected functionality?
COPX should show as per agreements in Inverness ACB and Scottish vMATS Pt 2

# How can it be reproduced? 
All traffic departing on routing GUSSI NESDI GOW (independent of whether the Airway is in the flight plan)

# Additional information
Possibly to do with sector levels. Since the delegation is DB(FL95 in this instance)-FL130 in N560, EuroScope is most likely predicting traffic will avoid the N560 delegation entirely.

title: GD -> FF Agreements Malfunctioning
body:
# What is the bug?
Aircraft inbound to Cardiff are given the GD -> FF agreements (FL80/3500ft on a heading) on all arrivals. I know why this is.

# What is the expected functionality?
Should be only for aircraft on the CDF 1C arrival.

# How can it be reproduced? 
Quite easily - plane comes in from the West, agreement shows. :(

# Additional information
Root cause of this is because I used the CDF as the level fix for prediction. Plan is to change this to the BRI so it can only possibly trigger for aircraft on the CDF 1C arrival.

title: Malfunctioning handoffs associated with PCSE
body:
# What is the bug?
Certain hand offs associated with PCSE (MAN_SE) seem to head to the wrong sectors. Following content copied from discord:

> had some issues with handoffs associated with MAN_SE - DAYNE arrivals were sent from PCSE-> CCF rather than CC1
there were also some other stuff associated with stuff that was supposed to go to MAN_SE but ended up with bbx - Alex Beavil

> I had the same issue with CCF when on as PCSE, seemed to start with CCS then around TNT turn to CCF and then go back to CCS again near DAYNE. I think the descent prediction was wrong - after DAYNE it goes directly to EGCC - maybe a fix SW/NE of DAYNE depending on the runway, in the RMA might help - or even just the CF for the runway might be sufficient - Chris Pawley

> Further to above, when on LM last night was being suggested PCSE for traffic +FL195 (on top of PCE airspace in ELVOS area) when should be sent LM -> PCW. Traffic was routing [...] BUZAD T420 TNT L28 AGLIL [...] - Dale Brooksby

title: Erroneous COPX: MTMA outbounds from via ARSAT
body:
# What is the bug?
When on as MAN_NE_CTR (though the same bug would occur if on as MAN_E_CTR) with MAN_W_CTR also online, traffic via POL-ARSAT is showing climbing FL190, which should only apply to traffic that turns left at POL to head towards RIBEL. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/113584146-74595c80-9622-11eb-8a23-fceeddfa501c.png)


# What is the expected functionality?
Traffic via the UP18 and UP17 should remain with NorthEast and is then given to Montrose 280 lvl ARSAT/TILNI

# How can it be reproduced? 
As described above

# Additional information
Likely solution is to make the COPX for via POL more specific, so to only apply to those flights with RIBEL as the FIXAFTER

https://github.com/VATSIM-UK/UK-Sector-File/blob/main/Agreements/Internal/North_S29.txt

title: won't fix: Malfunctioning COPX: NT inbounds from Daventry to PC NE
body:
# What is the bug?
EGNT inbounds from Daventry to PC NE not showing the agreement

# What is the expected functionality?
Agreement is either 280 level 25 miles before MAMUL, or 280 BETAX

# How can it be reproduced? 
On as LON_M_CTR with LON_N_CTR and MAN_NE_CTR online

# Additional information
I suspect it's because MAMUL is too far north of Sector 28's airspace, so EuroScope is predicting the traffic into North's airspace rather than PC NE. Not sure what the solution is though...

https://github.com/VATSIM-UK/UK-Sector-File/blob/main/Agreements/Internal/28_East.txt

title: Unnecessary Bristol FIN -> TWR Agreement
body:
# What is the bug/ error?
Investigate whether the "ILS at 2500" agreement between GD FIN and GD TWR is actually needed

# What is the expected functionality?
Quite simply, it looks annoying and I'd rather have an RFL displayed in the COPX entry. While it may be useful for some people, chances are the ones covering GD top-down will know the platform altitude

# How can it be reproduced? 
As LON W or GD APP/FIN, with GD TWR is online, this agreement will display in COPX

# Additional information
When creating the Bristol Director stuff, I set up a COPX "agreement" for GD FIN -> GD TWR. Not sure if this was needed so I will be investigating to see if it changes the functionality at all. If anyone knows if this is useful or not then please let me know - my aim is to remove the "agreement" from COPX but I'll happily be told not to

title: BBTWR ring not displaying to MPC without Daventry online
body:
# What is the bug?

- I was logged on covering PC East (Stafa & Trent)
- Birmingham Tower was online, who hands me northbound departures in the absence of BB APC (or their top-down), as per the latest version of the EGBB crib sheet 
- Central (Daventry/TC Midlands) was **not** online

# What is the expected functionality?

The BBTWR ring should display to both PC East sectors whenever BBAPC is not online, and independent of whether Central is online or not

# How can it be reproduced? 
As above

# Additional information
It doesn't matter in what order sector identifiers appear in this list, but all of the possible owners of Stafa/Trent sectors need to be added to this line: 
https://github.com/VATSIM-UK/UK-Sector-File/blob/c7b278f6cf957bdb9a1fe940c473fe7a3d36b135/Airports/EGBB/Ownership.txt#L11

Ownership of Stafa & Trent:
https://github.com/VATSIM-UK/UK-Sector-File/tree/main/Ownership/TC%20-%20MPC

title: EGDR's & EGHC's GEO Not getting compiled
body:
# Summary of issue/change

The GEOs for EGDR and EGHC are not being compiled into the sector file. This is due to their files being named 'GEO.txt' not 'Geo.txt' (the compiler is case-sensitive).

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

Options under 'Geo' in display settings with the 20-13 sector file:
![Display_Settings_Geo_List_2020-13_Highlighted](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61326713/102689784-c18efb00-41f8-11eb-99e4-0507aae8e63d.png)

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

/Airports/EGDR/SMR/GEO.txt
/Airports/EGHC/SMR/GEO.txt

title: Fixes #3154 - Updated French (Paris, Brest & Reims) Sectors
body:
Fixes #3154

# Summary of changes

- New French positions added - Paris Control sits underneath Brest Q sectors and Reims (pronounced Rance) N sectors
- French positions removed - Paris Upper has gone, Brest Upper has gone; France Control (245+) remains for now
- Sectorisation amended - as per convention, I haven't drawn the whole sector, but there are now LFRR Low, LFRR (high) N, LFRR E, LFRR Q, LFEE N and LFFF (low) sectors
- COPX updated to reflect new sector names
- Line display updated to reflect new sector names

All cruising traffic via SITET/XAMAB should be COPXed automatically to either the Q (355+) or E (295-355) sectors during CTP. LTMA departures have COPX for climbing FL330 - these should be handed to E, and must cross the FIR boundary 290+, else need to be coordinated with LFFF N (the low sector).

# Screenshots (if necessary)

**New positions**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/98951286-f7520d00-24f1-11eb-91d1-2d668eba782c.png)

**LFRR_N, LFRR_E/Q, LFEE_N**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/98949830-22d3f800-24f0-11eb-8f31-9173a65e67ec.png)

**As AC West - with AC South and Brest online**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/98951361-12248180-24f2-11eb-9141-2a3e883ff6b5.png)

**As AC Dover - with AC Worthing and Paris/Reims online****

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/98951487-36805e00-24f2-11eb-9a77-f61e094e6d0d.png)

title: Fixes #2980 - Fixed KB TWR online ring displaying erroneously
body:
Fixes #2980

# Summary of changes

After scowering through Sector Ownership settings in EuroScope, I found that the KB APP was owned by the wrong sector, causing ES to draw an online ring around it. I looked at the Ownership files and sure enough, someone missed the C off of "LON_SC_CTR", causing ES to select the wrong ownership setup when selecting "Observing LON_S_CTR".

title: Fixes #3039 - OCAS Regions to reflect conditional airspace.

labels.name: on-hold
labels.description: Pending scenery updates or an effective date

body:
Fixes #3039 

# Summary of changes

Adjusted both colour OCAS regions to reflect the nature of the conditional airspace. As most of these are only available a few days/hours a week, it shouldn't be filled in as CAS and should follow the convention used at the Cotswold FUA/Daventry CTA 10

It should be noted, TopSky draws the airspace when necessary, so controllers utilising it will automatically see the correct display depending on time/day/date. Users who don't utilise TopSky will still be able to select the ARTCC boundaries if/when required.

# Screenshots (if necessary)
Note: I've used the two different region colours to compare before/after but both have been edited in reality.

title: Fixes #2997 - Improve Border with EHAA/EBBU
body:
# WIP!

Fixes #2997 #3115

# Summary of changes

ARTCC High edits  from EKDK border to EBBU southern boundary to remove duplicate lines and dodgy coordinates:
- Clacton CTA
- London FIR
- Amstedam FIR
- IBNOS/ABNED/AMRIV delegated airspace
- Southern CTA

Implementation of ABNED/AMRIV Delegated airspace which replaces IBNOS areas B/C
Includes many corrections to brand new published AIP data (yay NATS) to ensure nice, non duplicated lines
Removal of SASKI area C (Area B lower limit FL245)

EBBU high sector ownership drawn better to now include area bordering SASKI delegated airspace and LFFF/EBBU cross border working area.

LON_D vs EBBU/EDYY_K line display now shows extent of the above cross border working area.

Amsterdam defintion not touched as it works perfectly fine as is.

Sectorlines updated to reflect updated AIP data

body:
Fixes #2696 

# Summary of changes

Fixed KK inbound via RAPIX Agreement not displaying. Thanks to Harry for the help and apologies for the outdated changelog, bit of an old branch :P

# Screenshots (if necessary)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18119316/93937045-ff29d800-fd1e-11ea-9c8d-fed157020534.png)

For the agreement to work, it requires the BULAM agreement to be placed above the FIR_COPX for RAPIX between EBBU and S13 - which it currently isn't. 

Harry says: "This will either need to be fixed by moving all the agreements between EBBU and S13/14 into a single file, 'BUhigh_E', or specifying the order the files should be compiled into the sector file with Andy's new generator".

title: Incorrect Magvar Value
body:
# Summary of issue/change

The value should be changed from -1.0 to 1.0 for reasons outlined below.

For some reason unknown to humanity, the SCT file format uses **positive** magvar to indicate deviation to the **west**, and **negative** values for **easterly** deviation. 

I've cross-checked this against two sector files from areas where magvar is much more significant than the UK (so you'd hope they have it right!) -- Boston and New Zealand. Boston has westerly variation and have a positive value in their SCT, New Zealand had easterly variation and has a negative value.

Thanks to @Robbo599 for noticing this :)

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

Info.txt

title: Fixes #2368 - Fixed SSFIN->TC NW NUGBO/UTAVA agreements
body:
Fixes #2368

# Summary of changes

The logic here is that:

- In the first instance, until the aircraft passes NUGBO/UTAVA, an agreement that will limit climb to FL70 will be matched. Along with the guest ownership, this has been tested to ensure that the suggested handoff is to TC NW.
- In case the aircraft passes west of NUGBO/UTAVA - which would not be uncommon if holding is taking place at LOREL - then a backup agreement will be identified to remind SSFIN of the conditions. At this stage, however, it does not need to limit climb since the aircraft's profile should take it well into TC NW's airspace.

I had tried setting the fix as SILVA/BUZAD, but this of course limited the climb until those fixes and upon assuming the tag as TC NW, it was not displaying the relevant agreement onwards to Worthing/Daventry until the aircraft had passed SILVA/BUZAD respectively.

# Screenshots (if necessary)

Pre-NUGBO

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/79630638-f408c580-814a-11ea-8a67-550d862209b5.png)

Post-NUGBO
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12017284/79630641-f834e300-814a-11ea-986d-43b764a8b770.png)

body:
Fixes #2371

# Summary of changes

- EGLL/EGWU/EGGW departures via MATCH optimised as discussed in the issue - using BRAIN as the FIX to limit the climb profile between TC NE -> TC DAGGA, and MATCH+DIGSU for LL/WU departures that turn left at MATCH

- Simplified COPX for EGLL/WU/GW/KK/KB departures between TC DAGGA and London S12, using FIXBEFORE, and ^BRAIN/DAGGA for situational awareness.

- Restricted climb for EGKK/KB FRANE departures, TC LAM -> TC DAGGA using FIX as DAGGA

Further investigation for TC SE -> TC LAM EGKK/KB FRANEs will be addressed separately in #2391.

title: EGSS NUGBO/UTAVA departures agreement
body:
# Summary of issue/change

As Clacton with Daventry online, Essex reported that no agreement was displaying for NUGBO departures runway 22. This will be the reason why:

`COPX:EGSS:22:D264E:*:*:SSFIN:London TC NW:7000:*:BKY+8`

The fix D264E no longer exists since the SID was truncated back to NUGBO.

On 04, BKY has been used for the agreement, but most of these aircraft will have passed BKY before transfer to TC NW in busier situations. Therefore, I think it makes sense to use a FIXAFTER for these in place of, or supplementary to:

`COPX:EGSS:04:BKY:*:*:SSFIN:London TC NW:7000:*:BKY+8`

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

EGTT vMATS LTC 3.4.2.1

title: Fix TCSE->LAM EGKK outbound agreement
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Once #2154 is merged, the new COPX from TC SE to TC LAM will read:

```
;fixme
COPX:EGKK:*:*:DET:*:London TC SE:London TC LAM:13000:*:^DET
COPX:EGKK:*:*:DET:*:London TC SE:London TC LAM:13000:*:^DET
```

Logged on as LON_S_CTR with LON_C_CTR, unassumed departure traffic correctly shows 130 ^DET in the Sector Inbound List. As soon as I assume the traffic as LON_S_CTR, it then does not predict the agreement in the Sector Exit List. Add TC NE to the equation, and it predicts that I should transfer the traffic to LON_C_CTR and not LTC_NE_CTR.

My guess is that this is because EuroScope doesn't think it will enter the TC LAM airspace anywhere between 130 and 175 (its top). I don't think there is a way in EuroScope of _forcing_ an agreement to activate regardless of the climb profile. This would have to be done through the EuroScope interface by the controller every time (i.e. COPX coordination, or just a manual transfer).

Question is then, how do we make this agreement function?!

I have attached a Sweatbox file with the relevant controllers to simulate and an EGKK FRANE departure! Initial pseudo pilot is set to LON_S_CTR
[KK FRANEs.txt](https://github.com/VATSIM-UK/UK-Sector-File/files/4046425/KK.FRANEs.txt)


# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

?

title: Various Fixes at Incorrect Coordinates
body:
# Summary of issue/change

EDIT: The chosen way forward to correct this is to match Navaids/FIXES_UK.txt to ENR 4.4.

Various fix coordinates in the sector file deviate from those given in ENR 4.4. In some cases this is because there is a mistake in the sector file which needs to be corrected. 

In other cases it is because the fix is associated with an aerodrome and is defined with greater precision in the relevant AD part of the AIP (ENR 4.4 gives fixes rounded to the nearest whole second whilst AD pages give it to hundredths of seconds). However, this is not consistent across aerodromes. As an example: 

- IMVUR (KK SID) is defined as 511028.90N 0003156.40W in AD 2-EGKK-6-13 and is rounded to 511029N 0003156W in ENR 4.4. 
- In this case we use the more precise value of N051.10.28.900 W000.31.56.400 in the sector file.
- BEDEK (LL STAR) is given as 512214.61N 0013331.13W in AD 2-EGLL-7-7 and is rounded to 512215N 0013331W in ENR 4.4. 
- In this case we use the rounded value of N051.22.15.000 W001.33.31.000 in the sector file.

In the worst case the maximum distance between the more precise and the rounded coordinates is around 20m and I suspect such a distance is imperceptibly small even on the biggest screen at normal zoom levels. Aligning all fix coordinates to the rounded values given in ENR 4.4 will allow a quick one-stop shop check for all fix locations in the UK in the future (Excel and Spreadsheet Compare makes this a doddle). 

@cpawley and @hsugden do you have any thoughts on this before I charge ahead?

Fixes that have more precision than ENR 4.4 and are related to SIDs/STARs:
- [x] ADMAG
- [x] AMTOD
- [x] DISVO
- [x] FIGZI
- [x] FITBO
- [x] GOSAM
- [x] IMVUR
- [x] LARCK
- [x] NEVIL
- [x] NOVMA
- [x] ODVIK
- [x] OSPOL
- [x] OTMET
- [x] SOKDU
- [x] TEBRA
- [x] TELTU
- [x] TIMBA


Fixes that have more precision than ENR 4.4 but not remarked as related to SIDs/STARs:
- [x] AGPED
- [x] AMPOP
- [x] ERING
- [x] GOXUL
- [x] INPIP
- [x] INREV
- [x] NEPNA
- [x] OVDAN
- [x] PENUN
- [x] TEVSI
- [x] UTUXA

Fixes that have mistakes and are related to SIDs/STARs:
- [x] BIFIN (BB)
- [x] NUGBO (SS)
- [x] UTAVA (SS)

Fixes that have mistakes and not related to SIDs/STARs:
- [x] ATWEL
- [x] BISRU
- [x] DEXEN
- [x] DIGSU
- [x] DOKEN
- [x] ELNAB
- [x] EPOXI
- [x] IPSAD
- [x] JOZMA
- [x] KUVOX
- [x] LANPI
- [x] SIDDI

title: Fixes #2130 - Added missing agreements for CC/GP inbounds S28->Tnt
body:
Fixes #2130

# Summary of changes

Added agreements via TNT and POL45.

Since TNT is well into Trent's sector, EuroScope wouldn't show the East controller the next agreement until they had passed TNT if this were to be used in the COPX. So my logic is that if their route doesn't match any of the other 3 agreements, then they still need to be level at FL200, 25 miles before TNT, so that can just be a catch-all!

title: Insufficient Sta_C agreements for MTMA outbounds
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Had an aircraft from EGGP with route NANTI L8 STAFA P18 TELBA UL151 KIDLI..., which is a valid route according to the SRD. Found that the agreements in Sta_C only cover EGCC/GP/NR outbounds routing via HON. This is insufficient to cover routes with RFL 195+ via H, E and V intention codes from all three airfields.

The agreed level for all of these outbounds with RFL 195+ is to be FL190 by the boundary between Stafa and our AC Daventry. This is marked with HON10. VIDOK is 3.7 miles from this boundary.

I propose:

- Agreements as at present, COPX HON, named HON10.
- Agreements for CC/GP/NR outbounds, COPX VIDOK, named VIDOK.
- Catch-all agreements for CC/GP/NR outbounds, COPX *, named HON10.

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

SRD

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

Agreements/Internal/Sta_C

title: SS NUGBO TC NW->AC Worthing agreement
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Noticed this bug when...
Logged on as TC Bandbox with AC Bandbox online (covering S, C, and W). EGSS departure (NUGBO) with route `NUGBO M183 SILVA Q41 SAM N63 LELNA` to EGJB, RFL 190.

Agreement 160 level 11 miles before CPT from London TC NW to London AC Worthing did not show, since the above route does not route via CPT. Instead, it's `NUGBO-SILVA-COWLY-NORRY-TABEN-PEPIS-SAM-etc.`

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

Lower airways ENR 3.3
SRD states the above is a valid routing - filtering SRD for ADEP EGSS and SID NUGBO shows a good number of routes out that way that no longer route via CPT

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

Agreements\Internal\TCNW_S

title: Runway formatting
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Some of the runway files do not have enough spacing, and it makes the sector file look uneven 😞 lol 

For runways with 2 digit designators, the designator should be followed by **2** spaces. For runways with 3 digit designators, the designator should be followed by 1 space.

title: Fixes #1103 - EGHI/HH BAMBO (150) C->TCNW corrected
body:
# Summary of changes

Copy of comment from the issue:

"My guess is that this has something to do with BAMBO being about 10 miles out of NW's airspace, and that the flight plan track for this routing only remains in NW's airspace for about 5 miles. I tried allowing TCNW to be a guest in Daventry's airspace, but this didn't seem to have an effect. However, changing the COPX point from BAMBO to EVSEM (just at the border between Daventry and TC NW's airspace) appears to make the agreement function correctly - though of course BAMBO is left as the label that the controller would see in the Sector Exist List.

I also checked (by logging on as TC NW on Sweatbox) that the 150 BAMBO appeared in the Sector Inbound List correctly, and that 110 RISIN for TC NW to TC SW displayed correctly once TC NW had the aircraft assumed."

title: Online ring ownership missing mentor/observer
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Many of the online rings that have been added since the EGTT Sector File became the UK Sector File do not have complete ownership definitions for the 'Only XXGND 2' and 'Only XXTWR 2' 'sectors'. Many have LM or SM (London/Scottish Mentor) and O (Observer) missed off.

Note Stansted's TWR 2 ownership:

SECTOR:Only SSTWR 2:0:0
OWNER:ESS:SSA:TCNW:TCNE:TCN:TCSW:TCSE:TCS:T:LE:LC:LD:LS:LWN:LNC:LWC:LWS:LSC:L:LM:O

Compare to the TWR 2 ownership for East Midlands:

SECTOR:Only NXTWR 2:0:0
OWNER:NXR:LC:LNC:LWC:LSC:L

... which **should** read ...

SECTOR:Only NXTWR 2:0:0
OWNER:NXR:LC:LNC:LWC:LSC:L:LM:O

For Glasgow:

SECTOR:Only PFTWR 2:0:0
OWNER:PFR:PFF:STW:ST:SD:SWD:S

**should** be

SECTOR:Only PFTWR 2:0:0
OWNER:PFR:PFF:STW:ST:SD:SWD:S:SM:O

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

The Ownership.txt file of all affected online rings (GND and TWR only).

I have **no idea** how many online rings this affects. The list does include EGNX, EGPF, EGPH, EGJJ, EGJA, EGJB, EGHI, EGHH, EGGD, EGFF - but that is not an exhaustive list.

I would suggest searching for 'GND 2' and 'TWR 2' in all the airfield Ownership files, and then checking every single occurrence of GND/TWR online rings!

title: London AC Dover SECTOR definition
body:
# Summary of issue/change

London AC Dover (excluding the La Manche areas) is defined as only one SECTOR (0-FL660). This causes conflicts of ownership of the airspace with Worthing and TCSE so should instead be defined as 4 SECTORs:
- 215-660 over London
- 195-660 main area over DVR
- 145-660 north of ALESO/GURLU
- 135-660 VABIK/KONAN area

The La Manche areas are defined correctly and should not be changed.

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

![ac dover](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31161777/29529289-fdbee494-8696-11e7-8050-ff6e1f758fec.JPG)

title: EGAA APP Frequencies mixed up
body:
# Summary of issue/change

Currently, the following frequencies exist for EGAA App positions:

- EGAA_APP: 128.500
- EGAA_F_APP: 120.900

From a discussion with Gregg Donohoe, these frequencies are the wrong way round - and F should be R:

- EGAA_APP: 120.900
- EGAA_R_APP: 128.500

EGAA_APP should be the Director position covering EGAA only, R_APP should be the wider position covering top down for EGAA & EGAC.

# Reference (amendment doc/official source/forum) incl. page number(s)

Existing member knowledge

title: Fixes #443 Carlisle (EGNC) online ring display to MAN
body:
# Summary of changes

- Added new 'Only NCTWR' sector
- Corrected 'Scottish AC XXXX' to 'Scottish PC XXXX'
- Display of TWR line to Scottish PC East/West now depends on the owner of Only NCTWR being different to that of Scottish PC East/West (i.e. whenever the position with ID 'NCT' is online, the ring will display)
- NCT and NCA should never be simultaneously online, so any dual line display that might result from the fix described above won't be an issue

title: MAN E to CC DAYNE arrival agreement
body:
In GitLab by @hsugden on Feb 6, 2016, 00:53

# Summary of issue/change

Agreement not functioning correctly, as report in ticket ES-00006

Note that the issue is _not_ to do with the names of the sectors in the agreement.

While the change from Scottish PC East to Trent isn't incorrect, it won't actually do anything, as both sectors have the same ownership priority - so it doesn't matter which name you put, the agreement will function.

The actual issue is that even with the agreement, EuroScope still does not predict CCS to be the next controller. 

![150601](/uploads/0bddf65378bd4f382598226f38f1735c/150601.png)

Note how the XFL is not 070 and the SI is not CCS.

Some of my thoughts with regard to how the problem could be solved...

1. Increase the vertical limits of the CCSTH23 sector from 6500 up to say 8500.

2. The line DAYNE - EGCC actually leaves the CCSTH23 sector, so perhaps EuroScope is predicting that the aircraft will not remain in that sector long enough to warrant a handoff. ![150857](/uploads/d233f9535d8e0c0357e12f402f5db7ba/150857.png)

3. Make CCS a guest controller in the Trent airspace. Examples of this are in Gatwick and Heathrow ownership, but basically the line GUEST:CCS:EGCC:* might make a difference...

# Affected areas of the sector file (if known)

Agreements\Airport\MAE_CC.txt

Airports\EGCC\Sector.txt ?

Airports\EGCC\Ownership.txt ?

Ownership\TC - MAN\Stafa.txt ?

"The order of the sectors in the file is extremely important. EuroScope will check if an airplane is inside a sector in the order defined in the file. Therefore the first match will be used and the rest is not tested at all. You can use this behaviour and create overlapping sectors. But be sure that the smaller is earlier in the list."

title: Generator: output order (Old 128)
body:
In GitLab by @A-Lawrence on Sep 20, 2015, 16:01

The output of the generator is currently in places determined by the lexicographical ordering of the filenames. This isn't ideal, because we should be able to name files logically without regard for how it affects.

EuroScope is quite awkward in the significance that it attaches to order, particularly in the ESE sections.

title: Auto-handoffs showing wrong frequency (Old 115)
body:
In GitLab by @A-Lawrence on Sep 20, 2015, 16:00

Reported by Andy Ford:

"A text BRI1C aircraft was handed to BB in accordance with the agreement - the tag went to the right controller, but the auto text in Euroscope came up with "London Control" and "127.425" as the handoff frequency.

"I had a LOREL4Q arrival that went to 127.420 as well. (He was on headings as uncapable of flying the STAR, if that means anything).

"I'm not entirely sure about the others - it was so busy it's possible I may have not noticed the K3's etc and assumed they were right."


Prior expertise from ES 3.1 would say that the order of [POSITIONS] in the ESE shouldn't make any difference, so this whole situation is impossible unless the LON_CTR controller was actually on 127.42. (127.42 is defined as an 'L' frequency in the ESE.)

However, with ES 3.2 being relatively new, we should perhaps keep a more open mind about this.

Also fix the order of the ESE positions so that the primary positions we actually use (i.e. 123.9 for LON_CTR) come first.

title: Stansted freetext labels (Old 109)
body:
In GitLab by @A-Lawrence on Sep 20, 2015, 16:00

Reported by Sam White:

At Stansted the freetext/labels for the taxiway 'Q' holding points ('Q3' and 'QR') are incorrectly positioned, and the taxiway 'P' holding points ('P3' and 'PR' are missing. I believe that the '[LABELS]' section in the sector file for Stansted should include something similar to the following entry:

"PR" N051.53.18.800 E000.14.37.150 standHold
"P3" N051.53.23.300 E000.14.40.900 standHold
"QR" N051.53.27.843 E000.14.50.040 standHold
"Q3" N051.53.32.007 E000.14.54.604 standHold
"Q1" N051.53.33.004 E000.14.52.873 standHold

And the deletion of the current 'Q3' and 'QR' holding points entries:

; "Q3" N051.53.23.300 E000.14.40.900 standHold
; "QR" N051.53.18.800 E000.14.37.150 standHold

So that the taxiway 'Q' holding points are correctly positioned and the taxiway 'P' holding points are added.
